author: timbeiko
content:
EOF decision summary: 

1. We will remove EOF from Fusaka, decision about other potential Fusaka EL EIPs will happen on the next ACDE, with a strong bias towards already CFI'd EIPs
2. For Glamsterdam, we were already planning to revamp the ACD process to bring in more external input into prioritization. EOF advocates may propose this as a core feature for the fork, but the process should be redesigned to accommodate more voices from the community (see: https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/reconfiguring-allcoredevs/23370)

I realize many people are disappointed with this outcome, including many who have spent years of their lives working on EOF. I'm sorry for not getting us to a clearer outcome earlier. It's in large part my fault that the process failed to "do better" earlier.

Again, I'm optimistic we can improve this going forward, but I realise this doesn't "undo" what went wrong with Pectra + Fusaka.

author: timbeiko
content: Full recording of the call: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M3DWaWbIB3s

author: sorpaas
content:
I want to bring attention to the community on the EVM64 proposal I'm working on: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/9687

This brings 64-bit operations to EVM, via prefix mode opcode `C0`, so that those computationally intensive contracts which does not need full 256-bit can save cycles and boost speed.

I probably plan to PfI it on Glamsterdam or after. And in the mean time I would really appreciate some early feedback!

author: gcolvin
content: The EVM is broken.  It does not even meet Turing's 1945 requirements for a minimal stack machine.  The  Ethereum Core Devs have proved unwilling or unable to fix it for a decade now.

author: big_tech_sux
content: https://x.com/big_tech_sux/status/1916943108761391537 some thoughts on the process issues here

author: pcaversaccio
content: I want to make it clear that while I've been critical of EOF, my intent has always been constructive and never meant to _disrespect_ the people who've been working on it for years. This debate represents an important moment of dissent within the Ethereum community, and I strongly disagree with the claim (as an outsider) that the core devs are unwilling to address issues with the EVM. The real problem lies in the process itself, particularly when it comes to getting all parties on the same page regarding the application layer. That's what needs to be fixed.

author: smartprogrammer
content: Most of the core devs were willing/are to fix it.

author: gcolvin
content: They have rejected multiple opportunities to do so.

author: gcolvin
content: And yes, the process is completely broken.
